office:body.text:p: This is the image caption in “CNXML Figure Caption” style. (Source: this source is in the “CNXML Cite style”)
Because you named each file with the chapter and section number as well as the section name, we don't need to put the title of the section at the top of this template.

Note that I always leave a blank line of style “Default” between two elements – even between an example and a note. That way the importer definitely knows when the example ends and when the note begins, for example.

Insert them by using the menus in Word/OpenOffice (“Insert > Picture > From File”). I inserted this cool picture of a shark. After you type another paragraph below the image, you can go back and place your cursor on the line under the image, type in the caption, and highlight and set the caption to the “CNXML Figure Caption” style. Then, if there is a source, you can highlight the source and set it to “CNXML Cite”.
After import, the image needs to be given an alt description. For my shark, I would say something like
<media id='randomlygeneratedid' display='block' alt='A shark swimming.'>

By the way, do note that if all your images are such hi-resolution as the shark above, the PDF of the book will be HUGE and many people will have trouble downloading it. This is just something to keep in mind for the future.
office:body.text:h: Links to figures, tables, and other chapters/sections

text:p.text:span: Sometimes you want to refer to the student to Figure 4, Table 2, or the section called “Newton's Second Law of Motion”. It would be good if each of those was a hyperlink directly to the figure, table, or section in question. You can only link to modules which are already published. First find the URL (like
) then highlight the section name (you can delete the quote marks) and choose from the menu to Insert > Hyperlink.

office:body.text:p: Links to figures or tables are easiest to put in after import, so usually in the Word document I mark them as Figure 4***, Table 2***, and “Newton's Second Law of Motion”*** if that section isn't yet published. That way it's easy to press CTRL+F to search for three asterisks and replace them with links. To link to Figure <number> or Table <number>, create a self closing link that looks like this:
<link target-id='idofthetableorfigure'/>

You can link to sections by just using the module ID, which is the m12345 number in the example URL above. Notice that this one is not a self-closing link, because we want the name of the module to become a link:
<link document='m12345'>Module name here</link>

This will be my table title***. There is no “CNXML Table Title” style, so this will import as a paragraph and after import we will have to move it to the table title slot. I'll leave a blank line after the title. Wow, this is a long title.

But in Microsoft Word I want to choose Insert > Object > Equation 3.0.

I also noticed that I had to put a times sign between the delta and the x, when of course they are actually one unit. We'll see how it imports. In MathML, it should look the same whether or not there is a times sign.

office:body.text:p: Calculating Force Using Newton’s Second Law (label***): Exercises inside of examples (title***). There is no good way to mark up exercises inside of examples. One thing is for certain: a CNXML Exercise (Solution) must have a CNXML Exercise (Problem) in front of it to import correctly. I would probably do the following, using the first part of “Example 2: Chris pushes a sled” from section 5.2 as a template. (But first, I'll remind you that exercises inside of examples need special markup and tags after import!) I'd put a note here that says: the following problem should be INSIDE this example***.

Chris starts pushing a 40.0-pound sled across smooth hard-packed snow. The force on the sled by Chris is approximately constant. He wears spiked shoes so he doesn’t slip. The initial velocity of the sled is 0.0 m/s, and it moves 4.0 meters in 2.0 seconds (inline list follows***).

text:list-item.text:p: Draw an appropriate free-body diagram for the sled.
What is the force on the sled by Chris?

Chris pushes the sled a distance of 4.0 meters with a constant force. The vertical forces on the sled balance. If we assume the force on the sled by snow (surface friction) is negligible, the net force on the sled is just the force that Chris applies. (***image goes here)

To calculate the force on the sled by Chris, we need Newton’s second law, F = ma . To use this equation, we need to know the mass of the sled in kilograms and the acceleration of the sled in meters per second squared. Neither of these is provided directly in the problem, so we will need to use other equations to calculate them first.

office:body.text:p: One thing I wasn't sure about was whether you wanted the section summaries to appear both in each individual section and also at the end of the chapter (that is, in two places), or if you just wanted the section summaries to be pulled to the end of the chapter (it appears only in one place). To get the section summaries to be pulled to the end of the chapter, after import you can copy everything inside of this section into the “Summary” box of the green “Metadata” tab at the top of the module. Only a limited set of CNXML is allowed there. For instance, you will need to delete the id numbers out of paragraphs and lists and other elements. If you only want the section summaries to appear at the end of the chapter, you can then delete this section from the module.

text:span.text:span: – I made this into a list. In the module summary on the “Metadata” page, a bulleted list is allowed.

text:p.text:span: – If you don't delete the section summary from the module, you can make the list neater by turning it into a labeled-item list. The list should look like <list id='listid' list-type='labeled-item'><item><label><term>Key term</term></label>Description of the key term</item>[...]</list>

office:body.text:p: Do you remember what to do with the conceptual questions?

After import, the Conceptual Questions <section> tag receives a @class='conceptual-questions' attribute and a @type='conceptual-questions' attribute. Then, as strange as this sounds, DELETE THE TITLE OF THE SECTION. The @class attribute will automatically put in a section title. Also, each exercise inside the Conceptual Questions section should get a @type='conceptual-questions' tag.
Remember to put a blank line of style “Default” between each element.
And not to put images inside of exercises.
This works just like the Conceptual Questions section.
Except using @class='problems-exercises' and @type='problems-exercises'.
